title: Monday, 4th September, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Morning

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live, btw

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Or Paris Hilton

PM11:01am

Left that to Kadhim

PM11:01am

https://ftalphavil...ng-crypto-project/

11:01 am

PM11:02am

PM11:02am

Who he, you say?

11:02 am
BE11:02am

Who he?

PM11:03am

Well, until recently he controlled almost 30% of HNA -- that Chinese thing doing a deal a day, until the authorities in China blew a whistle

PM11:04am

Here's the man.

11:03 am
PM11:04am

PM11:04am

Guan Jun

PM11:04am

11:04 am

Ah, right, the guy who's always referred to in the press as "shadowy," which is a euphemism for "we can't find anything useful on Factiva."

BE11:05am

What's he up here for?

PM11:05am

Yep, that's the one. Lucy Hornby in Beijing has been doing some terrific stuff for the FT on HNA.

11:04 am
PM11:05am

Latest is here

PM11:05am

https://www.ft.com...-a114-64af3c246926

PM11:05am

The Chinese man who – at least on paper – held 29 per cent of one of the nation’s most acquisitive private conglomerates has surfaced in a video posted online, without clarifying how his mysterious stake in airline-to financing conglomerate HNA slipped through regulatory scrutiny.

The identity of Guan Jun and how he came to hold such a large stake in one of China’s largest private firms is a mystery that has helped fuel explosive corruption allegations from an exiled Chinese businessman, write Lucy Hornby and Archie Zhang in Beijing.

The allegations have transfixed the Chinese elite against the background of political power jockeying, as Chinese president Xi Jinping tries to cement his control over the ruling Communist Party.

HNA executives had previously explained to the Financial Times that the large shareholding was simply held in Mr Guan’s name but in fact represented the interests of HNA insiders. The stake was transferred to Mr Guan from Bharat Bhise, an aviation executive now living in New York, and is was transferred again this year to a New York-based foundation.

11:05 am
PM11:05am

But you'll also want this link https://www.ft.com...-9d56-25f963e998b2

(@BornCynic: are you sure it wasn't a Homebase?)

PM11:09am

So Bryce, there's a real chance of serious military action on the Korean peninsula. Trump is threatening to cut off trade with China. There's also sorts of stress on the Russian front(s).

What's the Footsie doing?

But why not!?!?!!?

People say: "QE"

PM11:10am

Or "carry trade"

PM11:10am

Or "too much money on the sidelines, looking to get in"

11:10 am
BE11:10am

That's a very, very good question. Perhaps because it shouldn't, because history tells us that the "buy when the cannons sound" thing is more or less right.

BE11:11am

Perhaps because markets run less on sentiment than commentators such as us want to believe.

BE11:12am

How do you, for instance, put the threat of World War 3 into your Excel spreadsheet of M&S earnings over the next five years?

11:12 am
PM11:12am

The Kospi was down 1.2% overnight

BE11:12am

(@AFK: they probably spoke to someone from Edinburgh.)

Would you buy that at the first whiff of radiation?

11:13 am

I'm bewildered.

Between Kim, Trump and the ICO madness -- we're into new ground here

I'm thinking it's probably not going to be the case that the world is about to end, and if it does my iShares Stoxx 50 tracker probably won't be worth much anyway.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

So, may as well assume it doesn't. What's the alternative? Buy gold? Jees.

BE11:15am

So, yeah, we're risk off.

PM11:15am

Okay, so we proceed with this session with a geopolitical risk-free mindset

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Thumbs up

undefined
PM11:16am

New poster @broke-retailer asks about Fed and Harvey.

11:16 am
PM11:16am

That's a bit geopolitical

PM11:16am

But Bryce -- can you address?

BE11:16am

Yeah, we can cover that ground, though it's been covered at length elsewhere.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

The assumption is pause -- not because of Harvey, because without being callous one assumes the impact on a top-down view will be a blip on the data rather than a trend, but because the underlying data aren't strong enough for a hike.

BE11:18am

Deutsche incoming.

BE11:19am

■ The Fed has probably done enough on normalization for now and should take a well-earned break! The fact that they won’t yet, informs our strategy: stick with the risk off. We remain biased for core rates to continue to decline, curves staying frustratingly flat, and risk assets
hopefully in a holding pattern at least initially.
■ The need for disaster aid following Hurricane Harvey has reduced the risk that Congress fails to reach a deal on the debt limit, but it has also shortened the timeline to reach such an agreement. Markets largely seem unconcerned, though early October bills tell a different story. We continue to think the trades we highlighted last week offer good risk/reward and attractive entry levels as hedges for a debt ceiling debacle

11:19 am
BE11:19am

And Citi.

BE11:20am

(@Kadhim: I'm not believing anything until I hear it from a cartoonist.)

BE11:21am

Tapering is coming with balance sheet announcements by the ECB and the Fed set to see net asset purchases fall to zero by the end of 2018.
Policy rates are rising gradually too, but we believe that the global economy is strong enough to absorb a moderate monetary tightening.
Our growth and inflation forecasts remain unchanged at 3.1%YY for 2017 and 3.3% for 2018, up from 2.5% growth in 2016. This is slightly more positive than consensus.
Inflation in the AEs continues to lag expectations; however we expect US inflation to pick up sufficiently for the Fed to hike by 25bp in December and 75bp in 2018. Inflation is steady in other AEs and they appear willing to look through occasional undershoots.
Financial stability is probably the most significant threat to the global outlook. A sharp revaluation of asset prices, some of which currently look stretched, is our main concern.
Trade negotiations are another important area to watch. Significant changes are underway with a notable shift away from multi-lateralism.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

It's terrifically bromidic stuff, this.

BE11:22am

Financial stability is the other major potential impediment to policy normalization.
Many market valuations appear stretched and it is noticeable that financial market
conditions are an increasingly significant presence in central bankers' rhetoric.
Financial conditions are currently extremely loose, which may give central banks
more room to withdraw stimulus. However in order for policy adjustment to be
effective it implies some tightening of financial conditions. The most significant
risk for the global outlook, in our opinion, is that this manifests itself in a sharp
revaluation of asset prices.

BE11:23am

Anyway, that's enough macro.

11:23 am
undefined
PM11:23am

Few movers to note

PM11:23am

Acacia mining, for one

11:23 am
Acacia Mining PLC (ACA:LSE): Last: 188.30, down 18.8 (-9.08%), High: 201.00, Low: 176.20, Volume: 1.32m
BE11:24am

The inevitable has happened, as the inevitable tends to.

PM11:24am

On going train wreck, this one

11:24 am
PM11:24am

This has been developing for what? 6 months?

PM11:24am

https://www.invest...al-activity-at-bul---20170904070000P6E3D

PM11:24am

Sorry for broken link

11:24 am
BE11:24am

About that. And yep, Acacia had warned several times that it will mothball Bulyanhulu

BE11:25am

Now it has.

PM11:25am

I really don't understand the actions of the Tanzanian government here.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

The only surprise is that Acacia's moved to mothball before its (self imposed) September-end deadline. Which might show a pessimism about the outcome of talks, or it might just be reality.

PM11:26am

How are they going to get the likes of Anadarko to invest $$$$$ in off-shore gas if they have a record of treating foreign investors like this

PM11:27am

Ive got a lump of Shore on this

11:27 am
PM11:28am

Bulyanhulu underground suspended to protect balance sheet; positive cashflow expected by “early 2018”; production guidance reduced. With discussions between major shareholder Barrick Gold (TSX: ABX^, NR, CNP) still dragging (albeit at least still continuing), Acacia has decided to make good on its threat that Bulyanhulu would be put on care-and-maintenance, although it is not quite yet the end of Q3 2017.

According to Acacia, Bulyanhulu is currently suffering negative cash flow of c.US$15m/month (YTD: c.US$210m) as a result of the Tanzanian ban on concentrate exports (which was suddenly imposed in March 2017) and other deleterious changes bulldozed into place by the government (e.g. increased royalties, a so-called ‘clearing fee’ and the threat of potential expropriation of up to 50% interests on the back of disputed taxes). In order to return the mine to a cashflow-positive situation in “early 2018”, underground mining is to be halted, with processing of underground ore to cease “within four weeks”.

PM11:28am

This move to this “reduced operational state” is expected to be completed in three months, during which time Bulyanhulu is expected to incur c.US$5/m of cash outflows, settling to c.US$3m/month at ‘steady state’. There will also be once-off costs of US$20-25m and the unwinding of two months’ (c.US$35-40m) working capital. However, the costs should be partially offset by revenues from tailings retreatment (30-35koz/year), which is currently suspended due to on-going drought conditions, but should resume in October 2017.

Buzwagi is to “continue to operate in the ordinary course” in the meantime, although it is actually testing the feasibility of becoming a doré-only operation. According to Acacia, such a strategy could not be economically applied at Bulyanhulu due to the different nature of the ore.

PM11:28am

As a result of the above, Acacia expects full-year 2017 production to be 100koz Au less than the bottom of the previous 850-900koz guidance range. Cost guidance remains unchanged at US$880-920/oz AISC due to cost-saving initiatives and a further reduction in guided capex to US$160m (the once-off and on-going costs of Bulyanhulu’s reduced operational state being excluded). Acacia is looking at further ways of reducing cash outflows (it had US$107m of cash and US$71m of debt at the end of August 2017), which could include reducing corporate overheads, expansion drilling at North Mara, greendfield exploration and gold hedging.

11:28 am
PM11:28am

done

BE11:28am

Honestly? I couldn't give a stuff about whether or not Anadarko might want to pull investment. I'd rather places like Tanzania do all they can to defend their mineral rights, and the history of western companies coming in to help them isn't good enough to make a cutting-off-nose-in-spite of-face argument.

BE11:29am

Here's Caz.

11:28 am
PM11:29am

But the claims on Acacia have been crazy!

PM11:29am

Un-hinged

BE11:29am

Yeah, that's their negotiation strategy.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Easy for me to say it's unhinged. It's not my dog in the fight.

BE11:30am

Key points: (i) the decision has been made given the “unsustainable cash outflows” due to the export ban and will result in one-off costs of ~$55-65m, which is above prior indications; (ii) the decision aims to preserve the balance sheet where ACA’s net cash has reduced to $36m as at the end of August (gross cash $107m) vs. $91m at June; (iii) production guidance has been reduced by ~100koz to 750-800koz although AISC remain at $$880-920/oz (current JPMe ~850koz and $924/oz); and (iv) we believe the decision partly reflects the limited progress that appears to have been made with negotiations between Barrick Gold and the Tanzanian government, which remain ongoing. ACA remains the cheapest UK gold exposure (~0.6x P/NPV vs. peers' ~1.5x) but material uncertainty exists with the export ban, and we retain our Neutral recommendation.

PM11:01am

Should be TinhatTinhatTinhat, but it's not

11:30 am
PM11:30am

Shall we move on?

BE11:31am

RBC first, albeit stating the obvious.

BE11:31am

The decision to stem the cash outflows likely protects the optionality of the shares in a worst-case scenario, but increases the potential of more significant negative outcomes. Our 175p target price is based on a probability risked scenario analysis at $1,300/oz gold, which includes a 10% probability for nationalization/unpayable tax bill

Destiny Pharma

PM11:32am

11:32 am

PM11:33am

· A clinical stage biotechnology company - lead asset (XF-73) targets post-surgical bacterial infections in hospitals

· XF drugs have shown in studies to be safe, fast acting and have a unique low/no resistance profile

· XF-73 has multiple drivers for adoption in an area of global unmet medical need, with a potentially "fast track" route to regulatory approval in the US market

· XF-73 is significantly de-risked - five successful Phase I/IIa clinical trials completed to date showing rapid antibacterial action combined with evidence of a no/low resistance profile; next major clinical trial is Phase IIb in the US

· XF-73 is part of the Company's proprietary, anti-microbial drug platform "XF Drugs" with a new mechanism of rapid action - Destiny Pharma also has several earlier stage programmes

· Destiny Pharma has market exclusivity, including robust IP protection that potentially extends into 2030

· Clearly defined value creation opportunity, significant addressable markets, including blockbuster potential for XF-73's lead indication

· £15.3 million gross proceeds will be used primarily to advance XF-73 to complete a Phase IIb clinical trial

PM11:33am

This looks like a proper float -- ie one for capital formation, rather than simple pricing

11:33 am
PM11:33am

Cantor did the business

PM11:34am

What's this XF-73 thing?

PM11:34am

Seemingly it looks like this

11:34 am
PM11:34am

BE11:34am

That's ........ super.

PM11:34am

Just seeing whether Cantor have published on this

11:34 am
PM11:34am

Yes

PM11:34am

Andrew Keith

PM11:35am

XF-73 (molecule above!) has an ultra-rapid bacteria kill mechanism and acts significantly quicker than antibiotics. The mechanism of action is fundamentally different and the majority of patients respond within a day. No bacterial resistance has been seen and XF-73 has an unmatched profile when compared with other antibiotics.

11:35 am
PM11:35am

The potential market for Destiny is substantial and XF-73 is likely to be first to market in a new FDA indication in the US, the “Prevention of post-surgical Staphylococcus aureus infections including MRSA”. Infection is a significant risk and cost for hospitals, so any method of reducing it is extremely valuable. Over 40 million US surgical patients are at risk of post-surgical infection, with 20 million at high risk, and therefore guidelines are in place in major countries recommending the use of infection control measures to reduce the risk of post-surgical infections. The World Health Organization specifically recommends pre-surgical, nasal decolonisation and sales of XF-73 could amount to US $1.5 billion in the US and Europe alone. The 2016 US Cures Act directs the FDA to allow novel antimicrobial drug approval via a Limited Patient Pathway so, should Phase IIb data show similar results to Phase IIa, there is a good chance of early approval.

PM11:35am

So if the drug works, it's a big market

PM11:35am

The XF platform will provide additional candidates to XF-73, for example, XF-70 is currently in development for the treatment of skin and burn infections. XF drugs have also demonstrated activity against staphylococci within biofilms which is an advantageous feature as many antibiotics cannot act against such bacteria. These programmes should provide further upside for shareholders.

Considering the significant market opportunity, the undemanding valuation and the growing antimicrobial resistance problem, Destiny Pharma has been added to our best picks list below.

11:35 am
PM11:36am

PM11:36am

PM11:38am

Four of Reckitt Benckiser’s top 10 executives are quitting the British household consumer group, which is battling the lowest sales growth in its history.

The management upheaval comes as Reckitt faces the challenge of absorbing its biggest acquisition yet — the $18bn purchase of Mead Johnson, the US baby milk group — and recovers from June’s crippling cyber attack that prompted a sales warning.

BE11:39am

The soft soap from people close to Reckitt is that it's all coincidence that 40% of its executive team has suddenly exited.

11:39 am

PM11:39am

11:44 am

PM11:44am

11:48 am

11:49 am

BE11:50am

BE11:52am

There are a number of those both inside or outside Kazakhstan -- one of which has been mentioned already on the right! -- but since I can't backtest any info with the flack without worrying that they'll chuck out an RNS to ruin my day, we can't really say more right now.

@AFK: sorry, no.

BE11:54am

11:54 am
Victrex PLC (VCT:LSE): Last: 2,204, up 159 (+7.78%), High: 2,230, Low: 2,120, Volume: 311.15k
BE11:54am

They're not paying any tax!

BE11:54am

Well, not much.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

Tax rate this year of 12%, rather than 21% previously guided.

BE11:55am

Which means ~10% uplift in consensus EPS

BE11:56am

Though that doesn't change the div for this year. 57p/share + 52p regular

11:56 am
BE11:56am

You're assuming the prospects of a special keep going though.

BE11:57am

The lower tax rate is because of the Patent Box legislation, in case you care.

BE11:58am

I wasn't aware Patent Box existed to benefit companies of a £2bn market cap and a £100m cash pile, but there we go.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Here comes Singer.

BE11:58am

Victrex has announced a material reduction in its effective tax rate as a result of the Patent Box legislation. New guidance is for a tax rate of 12% (from 20% to 21% previously). This implies a consensus EPS upgrade of c.8%+ and a cash benefit will also be felt from 2018. Alongside this announcement, it has been confirmed that new CEO Jakob Sigurdsson has joined as CEO-designate, effective 1st September. Jakob will join the Board on 1st September. Dave Hummel will remain on the Board until the AGM in February and will retire from the company on 31st March 2018. The Board remains comfortable with current trading expectations. One implication of the new tax guidance, we believe, is an increased likelihood of a special dividend in 2018, as well as 2017, where a special is already highly likely and included in our forecasts. We increase our TP by 7.5% to 2150p and remain at HOLD, but supportive of this high quality business.

BE11:59am

And Liberum.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

iPhone has ceased to be a significant negative risk issue for a while as the company has guided to 150 tons volume this year or barely 3% of Group, despite the Iphone 8 ramp this Autumn. The CEO of rival Solvay, Jean-Pierre Clamedieu, told analysts on the 1H17 results call in August that the new PEEK plant Georgia USA is “still in ramp up mode” whereas the unit ‘was expected to come on stream in mid 2016’ in the original press release issued on 24/2/2015. We have long believed Solvay will be the biggest supplier of PEEK resin for iPhone. We think it had iPhone largely in its sights when it decided on the Georgia investment and can compete strongly in this area given resin is relatively commoditised compared to other Victrex materials. However there would appear to be a fair chance Victrex has some supply position initially on Iphone 8 given Solvay was only in the process of ramping output in August. Any position would be a bonus given low expectations

BE12:00pm

n the 9M trading update in late July Victrex said ‘’overall, our strong core business performance is more than offsetting lower Consumer Electronics and may now offer a degree of upside potential for the full year.’’ The indication was that the company was on track to beat consensus PBT expectations of £109m by a couple of millions due to strong trading in Auto, Electronics ex Apple resin contract, Industrial and General Resellers. Since then consensus has ticked up to £110.5m to reflect earlier comments.

Now it seems Hurricane Harvey is likely to have an impact on US O&G business and Aero has continued to see weak mix. Both areas are around 7-8% of Group volumes we believe. O&G’s biggest market is the US we believe and whilst there are no assets or people in the region business will be impacted. Aero supplies primarily Boeing and Airbus and is facing negative mix as content per aircraft is higher on their wide bodies, particularly A380 and B787 where their have been order deferrals The above factors may mean VCT no longer has potential to beat PBT expectations in FY17 but it remains on track to meet it unlike many offers exposed to O&G.

We still believe also that December FY results will be accompanied by a 50p special dividend declaration costing c£42m. Victrex has committed to paying a special divi when net cash reaches around £80-85m and most brokers expect that to be reached at year end even if there is a small working capital build associated with iPhone ramp or other customer programmes. With EBITDA margin above 40% and Capex/Sales around 10% VCT remains one of the most cash generation companies in the FTSE350.
